[[Image:Beatty St opening 1901.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Opening of the armoury, 30 September 1901.]] The '''Beatty Street Drill Hall''' is a [[Canadian Forces]] armoury located at 620 Beatty Street in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. It is the home of [[The British Columbia Regiment (Duke of Connaught's Own)]], an armoured [[reconnaissance]] reserve regiment, the oldest military unit in Vancouver, and the most senior militia in the province.
==Architecture== [[File:BeattyStDrillHallII.jpg|thumb|left|Beatty Street Drill Hall, Vancouver, BC, Canada]] The building was designed by architect T.W. Fuller and opened on 30 September 1901 by the [[Duke of Cornwall]] (later [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]]). With two large castle-like [[turrets]] complete with [[battlements]], and two tanks and a 64-pounder [[Artillery|Gun]] alongside the large white structure, Beatty Street Drill Hall has long been a Vancouver landmark and is listed as a class-A heritage building.<ref>[http://www.bcregiment.com/ "A Proud History,"] British Columbia Regiment (Duke of Connaught's Own). Retrieved 24 March 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.heritagevancouver.org/topten/2003/topten2003_05.html 2003 Top Ten Endangered Sites,"] Heritage Vancouver. Retrieved 24 March 2007</ref> The walls are three and a half feet thick, and the building rests on huge granite blocks. Limestone from [[Gabriola Island]] was used for the parapet and it features a rusticated stone trim.<ref>[http://www.city.vancouver.bc.ca/ctyclerk/archives/exhibits/Ghosts%20of%20Vancouver.htm "Ghosts of Vancouver: Our City's Best-Known Haunts,"] City of Vancouver Archives. Retrieved 24 March 2007.</ref>
The Drill Hall includes a parade square, offices, and store rooms. It formerly contained a firing range and bowling alley.<ref>[http://www.cadets.net/pac/2290army/2_About%202290/02_2290%20History%20of%20Cadet%20Corps.htm "A Brief History of British Columbia Regiment and Beatty Street Drill Hall,"] 2290 BCR Army Cadet Corps website. Retrieved 24 March 2007.</ref> Originally, the [[Larwill Park|Cambie Street Grounds]], now a parking lot across the street, was also used as part of the regiment's training facilities.
==Memorials==
A stone cairn was dedicated to the local war dead of the First and Second World Wars and the local veterans of the Korean War and peacekeeping. Presented by the grateful Dutch Canadians of Vancouver in 1970, a copper plaque is dedicated to the memory of the B.C. Regiment who helped liberate Holland in the 1944 - 1945 campaign.<ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/mdsr-rdr-eng.asp?PID=6516 liberation of Holland]</ref> A wooden Celtic cross was dedicated to the officers, NCO's and men who fell at Vimy Ridge.<ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/mdsr-rdr-eng.asp?PID=6518 Vimy Ridge]</ref> A wooden Celtic cross was erected by their fellow officers and men in honour of the men of the 28th Canadian Armoured Regiment <ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/mdsr-rdr-eng.asp?PID=6520 28th Canadian Armoured Regiment]</ref> who died while serving in the Second World War.<ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/lm-eng.asp Memorials at Beatty Street Drill Hall]</ref> A plaque is dedicated to members of the 6th Regiment Duke of Connaught's Own Rifles who lost their lives in South African War of 1899 - 1902. <ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/mdsr-rdr-eng.asp?PID=6517 6th Regiment Duke of Connaught's Own Rifles]</ref> A plaque was dedicated to Lt. Colonel George McSpadden and the fallen heroes of the 11th Regiment Irish Fusiliers of Canada.<ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/mdsr-rdr-eng.asp?PID=6519 Lt. Colonel George McSpadden]</ref> A plaque was dedicated 17 October 1994 to commemorate the affiliation of {{HMCS|Vancouver|FFH 331}} and the B.C. Regiment.<ref>[http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/nic-inm/sm-rm/mdsr-rdr-eng.asp?PID=6521 HMCS Vancouver]</ref>
==Regimental Museum of the BC Regiment ==
[[File:BC Regiment Museum collection, Vancouver.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|A selection of the collection at the BCR Museum]]
The '''Regimental Museum of the BC Regiment''' (DCO) is housed in the Beatty Street Drill Hall, [[Metro Vancouver]]. Military displays date back to 1883, including uniforms, weapons, medals, [[Nazi]] [[regalia]], and a large collection of photographs documenting the history and artifacts of [[The British Columbia Regiment (Duke of Connaught's Own)]] and the Beatty Street Drill Hall. The museum was established in 1982 and is open to the public Wednesdays.<ref>[http://www.army.dnd.ca/BCREGIMENT/museum.htm "The Regimental Museum,"] The British Columbia Regiment, (DCO) page on the [[Department of National Defence and the Canadian Forces|DND]] website. Retrieved 24 March 2007.</ref> In addition to the BC Regiment (DCO), the 2290 British Columbia Regiment (Duke of Connaught's Own) Cadet Corps also parades at the armoury.<ref>[http://www.cadets.net/pac/2290army/2_About%202290/02_2290%20History%20of%20Cadet%20Corps.htm "History 2290 BCR Army Cadet Corps,"] 2290 BCR Army Cadet Corps page on the DND website. Retrieved 24 March 2007.</ref>
